{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3541624,"name":"James","username":"JamerGamer789","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/e19b73/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-26T18:19:26.256Z","cooked":"

With both the VH-109 and the white radios from last year, we experience occasional radio connection dropouts. We have tried narrowing it down but have yet to find the cause. Sometimes the connection loss is quick and returns, other times it disables our robot. This is what we have done to ensure we don’t have connection issues.

  1. Updated driverstation
  2. Firewall on laptop is off
  3. Switched from VH radio to white radio to isolate if it is one particular radio
  4. VH radio is on firmware 13.0.0
  5. All ethernet connections are clipped and not falling out of ports

It is a very strange issue. We don’t think it is power because we would expect to lose the radio for longer while it boots up again. We are powering with POE from the PDH on a 10 amp breaker.

Is it possible an ethernet cable somewhere along the chain is bad?

Thanks for the help!

How are you connecting your driver station to the VH-109? Using the 2.4GHz DIP switch, or using a second radio?

Also, can you access the radio at http://radio.local

Here are the “Practice At Home” connection methods: Practicing At Home | FIRST FRC Radio

We are using the 2.4 GHz connection on the VH-109. The problem is we also experience the same issues with the white radios from last year, in which we never had consistent connection problems

To rule out power you can run the additional 12VDC line

image1200×930 121 KB

Then while you’re testing run a constant ping to radio.local

If you’re also experiencing problems with the white radios, my best guess would be that either there’s a lot of 2.4 GHz interference in your space (in which case, using a second radio and 6 GHz would work better) or your computer’s wifi card is flaky (check for driver updates, and that your antenna connectors are seated securely if applicable).

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-02-26T18:42:21.589Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":64,"readers_count":63,"score":32.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":493360,"topic_slug":"radio-connection-issues","display_username":"Alex","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56260,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6238 alum (he/they)"},"post_url":"/t/radio-connection-issues/493360/5","custom_user_title":"6238 alum (he/they)","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3541700,"name":"","username":"EmerqldWither","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/emerqldwither/{size}/226176_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-26T19:09:39.826Z","cooked":"

The 2.4GHz of the Radio isn’t really designed to be used that much (and was kind of added as an afterthought since it was part of the chip that they use). The recommended solution is to use a 2nd VH-109 radio as an access point, and to tell the Radio to connect to this 2nd radio to effectively use the 6GHz feature.

We used the radio in different locations. Both at our school and a practice field. I’ll check for driver updates and see if that makes a difference

I’d say the effective range on the 109 running 2.4Ghz is 15-20ft. The docs clearly recommend against using it. Of course we had to find out for ourselves too….
